title: Newsome v. State
text:
THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Buddy Newsome, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Pickens County
Â John C. Few, Post Conviction Relief Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2006-MO-026
Reheard November 1, 2007 â€“ Refiled
  February 4, 2008
DISMISSED


	
		
			
				Chief Appellate
  Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent
  Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Karen
  C. Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  We previously granted certiorari to determine whether the
  post-conviction relief (PCR) court erred by granting Petitioner a new trial on
  the grounds that the Department of Corrections was incorrectly treating Petitioner
  as if he were ineligible for parole.Â  We affirmed the PCR courtâ€™s decision in
  an unpublished opinion.Â  See Newsome v. State, Op. No.
  2006-MO-026 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed July, 17 2006).Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s
  request for rehearing, directed
  the parties to brief certain issues on rehearing, and we find that the appeal
  should be dismissed as moot.
Factual/Procedural
  Background
Petitioner pled guilty to homicide by child abuse and attempted
  escape. The trial court sentenced Petitioner to imprisonment for 100 years on
  the homicide by child abuse charge, and one year imprisonment for the escape
  charge.Â  The court did not state whether the sentences were to be concurrent or
  consecutive.
In
  seeking PCR, Petitioner claimed that his sentences should be served concurrently
  so that the Department of Corrections would consider him to be eligible for
  parole.Â  The PCR court granted relief, and the State sought review on
  certiorari in this Court.Â  This Court affirmed the PCR courtâ€™s grant of relief,
  but ordered that Petitioner be given a new trial because the PCR court did not
  have the authority to order the Department of Corrections to interpret
  Petitionerâ€™s sentences as concurrent.Â  Newsome v. State, Op. No.
  2006-MO-026 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed July, 17 2006).Â  This Court granted the
  Stateâ€™s request that the Court rehear the matter, and the Court further
  directed the parties to brief the following issue:

	Assuming
  that the sentences in this case are consecutive, did this have any impact on Petitionerâ€™s
  parole eligibility?[1]

Law/Analysis
Petitioner testified at his second PCR hearing that he
  would not have pled guilty had he known he would not be eligible for parole.Â  The
  record on rehearing, however, reveals that the Department of Probation, Parole,
  and Pardon Services has been treating Petitioner as eligible for parole for
  some time, and that Petitioner has had several parole hearings.Â  Thus,
  Petitioner has received his requested relief.
Because
  Petitioner is being treated as eligible for parole, the appeal is dismissed as
  moot.Â  See Mathis v. South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 260
  S.C. 344, 195 S.E.2d 713 (1973) (case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered,
  will have no practical legal effect upon existing controversy; this is true
  when some event occurs making it impossible for reviewing court to grant
  effectual relief). Â Our finding that the appeal
  should be dismissed as moot makes it unnecessary to address the issues we
  previously ordered the parties to brief.Â  Cf. Whiteside
    v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (appellate
  court need not address remaining issue when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justices E. C. Burnett, III and Alexander S.
  Macaulay, concur.

[1] Although we asked the parties to brief three specific issues on rehearing, the
  resolution of this case calls for this Court to focus only on this single
  issue.

PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks
  a writ of certiorari from the denial of his application for post-conviction
  relief (PCR).Â  We deny the petition as to petitionerâ€™s Questions 2 and 3.
Because
  there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that petitioner
  did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we
  grant certiorari on petitionerâ€™s Question 1, dispense with further briefing, and
  proceed with a review of the direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State,
  288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).

Petitionerâ€™s
  appeal is dismissed, after review pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738, 87 S.Ct. 1396, 18 L.Ed.2d 493 (1967).Â

DISMISSED.

title: John Doe v. Baby Boy
text:
THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				John and Jane
      Doe, Adoptive Couple, Respondents,
				v.
				Baby Boy, a
      minor child under the age of fourteen years; and Birth Father, Defendants,
				of whom Birth
      Father is Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Greenville County
Â Timothy L. Brown, Family Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-009
Heard January 22, 2008 â€“ Filed February
  11, 2008Â   
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Robert
  L. Widener, of McNair Law Firm, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Raymond
  William Godwin, of Greenville, for Respondents.
				Stephen
  A. Yacobi, of Yacobi Law Firm, of Greenville, Guardian Ad Litem.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  The Notice of Appeal was not timely
  served, however, we exercise our prerogative and issue a common law writ of
  certiorari to review the family court order.Â  See Ray v. State,
  330 S.C. 184, 498 S.E.2d 640, n.1 (1998).Â  The scope of our appellate review is
  therefore limited to the correction of errors of law.Â  E.g., Rowe v.
    City of West Columbia, 334 S.C. 400, 513 S.E.2d 379 (Ct. App. 1999).Â 
  Applying this standard, we find no reversible error in the family courtâ€™s
  denial of appellantâ€™s request for a continuance, nor in the ruling that
  appellant did not satisfy the consent/relinquishment provision of S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 20-7-1690(A)(5).Â  Even if we were to reach the courtâ€™s alternative ruling
  that there was evidence to warrant termination of appellantâ€™s rights, we would
  find no error of law.
The
  order under appeal is therefore
AFFIRMED. [1]
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.



[1] We note that we would have reached the same conclusion had the appeal been
  timely, permitting the Court to take its own view of the evidence.

text:

  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Mary Ruth Metze, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-010
Heard January 10, 2008 â€“ Filed February
  11, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Elizabeth A. Franklin, of South Carolina
  Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, Assistant Attorney General Michelle J.
  Parsons, all of Columbia, and Â Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Affirmed
  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following
  authorities: Bell v. Clinton Oil Mill, 129 S.C. 242, 124 S.E. 7
  (1924) (to constitute breach of trust
  with fraudulent intent as to property received in trust, there must be an
  appropriation thereof, accompanied by a fraudulent purpose to destroy the right
  of the true owner); and State v. Parris, 363 S.C. 477, 611 S.E.2d 501
  (2005) (on appeal from the denial of a directed verdict, an appellate court
  must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, and if there
  is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably
  tending to prove the guilt of the accused, the Court must find the case was
  properly submitted to the jury).
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.
